body.head: PCT 23: In the days of the small-pox

p.seg: ispîh k-ômikihk êwakô âcimowin . This story took place at the time of the smallpox.
êkwah kîtahtawê nâ kisêyiniw âhkosiw , itah êh-kapêsicik . A certain old man took sick where they were encamped.
êkwah otâpâsôw , êh-pimipicicik . He was driving his team, for they were on the trek.
êkwah itah êh-kapêsicik , êkotah mistahi âhkosiw kisêyiniw anah . And then, there where they camped, that old man became very sick.
omis îsiyîhkâsôw awa kisêyiniw : pitikwayasit isiyîhkâsôw . This was the old man's name: Club-Foot was his name.
êwakô mistahi k-âhkosit . He was the one who fell very sick.
êkwah nêwâw êh-tipiskâk , êkwah pimisin ; wîh-nipiw . For four nights he lay there; he was at the point of death.
êkwah êkotah piciwak ôki kotakak ayîsiyiniwak ; Then the other people there moved camp;
mâcikah nakatâwak pêyak mîkiwâhp . as was to be expected, that family was abandoned there.
pêyak nôtokêsiw êkwah oskinîkiskwêw pêyak ; êwakô êkâ kâ-wâpit aw oskinîkiskwêw ; mistahi kitimâkisiw . An old woman and a young woman; and this young woman was blind; she was pitiable indeed.
êkwah namoya kîh-nahastâwak . They were not able to arrange their house.
êh-nipit êkotah wîkimêwak ; êkotah awa kisêyiniw pimisin . When the old man died, they stayed there with him; there lay the old man.
êkwah nîso-tipiskâw wîkimêwak . For two nights they stayed with him.
êkwah awa nôtokêsiw âhkosiw . Then the old woman took sick.
êkwah nîso-tipiskâw êtahtaw pimâtisiw . For two nights she barely lived.
âsay kêkâc êh-wâpahk , namoya pimâtisiw ; nipiw awa nôtokêsiw . When it was almost dawn, she was no longer alive; the old woman had died.
êkwah êkotah pêyakôw êkâh kâ-wâpit oskinîkiskwêw , okâwiyah kâ-nipiyit . Then that blind young woman was alone there, she whose mother had died.

êkwah êkotah ,
tânisi nika-tôtên ? êkosi itêyihtam ; Then, “What shall I do?” she thought;

seg.gloss: “I shall not go away from here;

p.seg: nîst ôtah nika-nipin , itêyihtam . I too shall die in this place,” she thought.
êkwah êkotah ayâw . So she stayed there.

seg.gloss: “In any case I too shall die.”

p.seg:
êkwah okâwiyah ôhi kîtahtawê ,
hâw , ntânis , sipwêhtê ; niyah ! Then suddenly her mother said to her, “Now, my daughter, depart from here; go!
anohc sipwêhtê , êh-itikot , êh-cîpayamatisôstawât ; Depart even now!” she said to her, speaking as the spirit of one departed to one still alive,
misatimwak nisto âh-ayâwêw , pêyak mistacimosis ; nêô . She had three horses and one foal; four.

hâw ,
êhag , nika-sipwêhtân , itwêw . “Very well, I shall depart,” she answered.

seg.gloss: “But where, I wonder, is the road?

p.seg: nama nkiskêyihtên , êkosi itêyihtam . I do not know,”
hâw , wawêyîw . So then she made ready.
êkwah misatimwah takosiniyiwa . The horses came to where she was.
êkwah êkotah otinêw ôhi misatimwah . Then she took hold of those horses.
êkwah tah-tahkopitêw : êkwah aspapiwin , wiyahpicikêw . She hitched them up; she took a saddle and harnessed them.
êkwah mâtôw . Then she wept.
oma wayawîw . She went out of the tent.
êkwah apisîs iwahikanisah êkotah aspapiwinihk tahkopitêw . apisîs pimîs . A little chopped meat she tied there to the saddle, and a bit of fat.
otinêw ôhtâwiyah ocistêmâw-maskimotisiyiw ; asiwatâw . She took her father's tobacco-pouch; she put it into her garment.
maskihkîwâpoy otinam , mîn âskihkosah , wiyâkanis . êkwah kâ-sipwêhtêt . She took some tea, and a small kettle, and a cup, and set out.
mâtôw . She wept.
tânisi êtokê nka-pimâtisin ? itêyihtam ; “I wonder how I shall keep alive”, she thought;
sipwêhtêw ; misatimwah sakâpêkinêw . She set out; she led the horses on the lines.
êkwah mêskanaw ntonam . She sought the road.
êkwah ositah ohci mêskanaw êh-ntonahk , piyisk miskam mêskanaw . Seeking the road with her feet, at last she found it.
êkoyikohk sipwêhtêw . Then she set out.
mâtôw êh-pimohtêt . She wept as she walked on.
mâskôc nika-nipin , itêyihtam . “No doubt I shall die,” she thought.
êkwah êh-pimohtêt wâhyam itohtêw . She walked a long ways.
êkwah omisi êh-têhtapit . So then she mounted a horse.
misatimwak sipwêhtêwak ; pimpahtâwak . The horses set out; they trotted on.
pêyak kîsikâw kinwês pimipahtâwak misatimwak . On the first day the horses trotted quite a long time.

piyisk kiskêyihtam :
tipiskâw êkwah . At last she knew that night was at hand.

kiskêyihtam :
sakâw ; oma mêskanaw , sakâw . She knew that there was a grove of trees: “Here is the road, here the grove.”
itohtêw sakâhk ; êkotah kapêsiw . She went into the wood; there she camped.
namoya nipâw . She did not sleep.
êh-wâpahk êkwah sipwêhtêw ; ntonam mîna mêskanaw . At daybreak she set out again; again she sought the road.
omisi minah ositah , mêskanaw nitonam . Like this, with her feet, she sought the road.
miskam mêskanaw . She found the road.
âsê min êkwah têhtapiw . Again she mounted.
sipwêhtêw , mêskanaw ; pimpahtâwak misatimwak . She set out on the road; the horses trotted along.
nama kêkway nipiy ôtah ayâw ; nôhtêyâpâkwêw . She had no water; she was thirsty.
kîtahtawê - misatimwah , pimipahtâwak misatimwak , - nipiy miskam . Presently - the horses were trotting along, - she found some water.
minihkwêwak êkwah êkotah misatimwak min âna îskwêw . Then the horses and that woman drank there.
êkotah mistatimwak mêskanaw êkwah miskamwak . the horses found the road.
pimpahtâwak misatimwak . The horses trotted along.
êh-tipiskâk nipâw ; mina kapêsiw . When night fell she slept; she camped again.

kîtahtawê misatimwak ,
brrr ! Suddenly the horses went, “Brrr!”
wîh-tapasîwak . They wanted to run away.
sêkisiw . She grew frightened.
kî-sakahpitêw . She had tied them up.
otinêw ; âsa mina têhtapiw . She took them; she mounted one.
tapasîw . She fled.
nama kêkway mêskanaw . The road was not there.
itê minah êh-tipiskâk kapêsiw . Then again when night fell, she camped.
nipiy êkotah ayâyiw , sâkahikan . there was some water, a lake.
êh-wâpahk , sipwêhtêw . At daybreak she went from there.
nama kêkway âsay mîcisôwin . By this time she had nothing to eat.
mêstinam mîciwin . She had eaten all her food.
si-pimohtêw ; têhtapiw . She went on, riding.
tântêh êtokê ? itêyihtam . “Whither, I wonder,” she thought.
mêkwâc êh-pimohtêt , kîtahtawê nipiy pahkopêwak ôki misatimwak . As she went along, presently the horses were going into water.
piyisk oma timîw . At last it came as high as this.
wâyoniw . She turned back.
sipwêhtêw mînah . She set out again.
wâhyaw êkwah itêyihtam . She thought it a long ways.
oma êh-sipwêhtêt , omah ispatinâw kiskêyihtam , êh-âmaciwêt , mistah êh-spatinâyik . Here when she set out, she knew that it was a hill, that she was going up a high hill.
êkotê têhtapiw . She rode there.
tahkôhcâyîhk pêyakwanohk nîhtakosiw . On top of the hill in a place, she dismounted.
mâtôw . She wept.
kîtahtawê apiw . Then she was sitting there.

kîtahtawê misatimwak ôki sêkisiwak ,
prrr ! Presently the horses grew frightened; “Brrr!”
wîh-tapasîwak . They made to run away.
apiw . She sat there.
mâskôc nika-pakamahok iyahciyiniwak ; nika-nipahikwak , itêyihtam . “Perhaps the Blackfoot will strike me down; they will kill me,” she thought.
ocêmik . Someone kissed her.
mâtôw iskwêw awah . The woman wept.
hâw , kika-pimâtisin , itik , nêhiyawah êh-miskâkot . “There, your life is saved,” they told her, for some Cree had found her.
mistahi pakwâtam ana nâpêw ê-kitimâkisiyit ôhi iskwêwah . That man was greatly disturbed at the woman's plight.
êkos îsi otihtahêw kisiwâk mîkiwâhpah , êh-kîwêhtahât . So he took her to some tents that were close by, he took her home with him.
takosin mîkîwâhpihk . He arrived at the camp.
awa nâpêw mistahi miyw-ayâw . That man was very well off.
hâ , nama kêkway cistêmâw , itêw . “I haven't any tobacco,” he said to her.
ow îskwêw otinêw cistêmâwah ; miyêw ôhi nâpêwah ôhi , maskihkîwâpoy mînah . The woman took the tobacco; she gave it to that man, and the tea as well.

êkotah ,
mistahi kitatamihin , itwêw awa nâpêw êh-miyiht cistêmâwah . Then, “You are doing me a great kindness,” said the man when he was given the tobacco.
êkwah êkotah kîh-pimâtisiw an îskwêw . And there that woman was able to live.
êkosi êkoyikohk oma âcimown êh-iskwâk . So that is the end of this tale.
niki-wâpamâw ana yskwêw ; mina nâpêw ana ninisitawêyimâw kâ-kîh-miskawât . I saw that woman; and I knew the man who found her.
